content.description: The crux of this route is placing gear. Overall the moves are challenging and consistent but difficult gear placements makes them all the more scary! Here is one description: Start by picking a start.  Climb either side of the prow to a blocky stance.  The original line (left side) is more aesthetic, and easier to get off of the ground, but more tedious to protect (.5in to 1.5in) than the variation, which is harder to get off of the ground, but easier to protect (3in to 4in).  At the blocky stance, the line tends left, past semi-overhangs, to the base of a long, right-angling, diagonal crack (2.25in).  DonÂ’t take this crack (Bro Frontiers Right / 5.7), but instead, continue angling up and left, aiming for the middle (dark waterstreak) of the upper headwall.  This upper headwall is characterized by sporadic pro, and committing moves off of good stances, spine-tingling stuff. Definitely worth the effort!
content.protection: Small stuff. Micro Stoppers at some points or run it out. The are very solid spots but they are far between!
content.location: See Lohn Guide if you really want to find it.

climbs.name: Tuberculosis
climbs.fa: Ken Rose, Jay Lowell, Kenny6 Stearns, 1974

content.description: The only good looking line on the wall, though Afterburner is the choice of lines.  The route follows the obvious angling corner to the large window.
30 ft left of tyro rumpus. Climb up through the overhanging rock onto the face and anchors shared with tyro rumpus. 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: 30 ft right of tyro rumpus. Same side of the creek as window rock.

content.protection: Rack up to 3", no fixed anchors up top.

content.description: Thin sharp crimpers on brittle rock.
content.location: On the upper left side of window rock.

content.description: Thin sharp crimpers on brittle rock.  The run out between the 1st and 2nd bolts is pretty long and scary.  Bring your Quartz Mountain nerve.
content.protection: Two bolts, there is not a bolted anchor on top of these climbs as the guidebook says.
content.location: On the upper left side of Window Rock.  To access this route you must rap from the top of Window Rock.  Be sure to locate the 2nd bolt, as it cannot be seen from the belay stance.

content.description: Very cool climb on the right side of window rock. Very noticable crack splitting a slab under a large 6ft roof. Overcome the first bulge, walk up cracked slab, and enjoy the juggy overhanging roof to the anchors.
content.protection: up to .75 camalot, one bolt under roof and two bolted anchor
content.location: Right side of window rock. No fixed anchors up top.

content.description: Plenty of shade here late in the day.  Rock can be a little questionable but is still nice.
